blog.title: Tijekom svojih đirada po Dalmaci, došao sam i do čuvene kuće Mimbelli u Orebiću.

blog_graphql.tekstBlogaEng:
During my peregrinations through Dalmatia and my visitations to the oldest and most charismatic houses, I finally came to the famed house Mimbelli in Orebić. I heard people talk about this beauty on many occasions and I was planning to photograph it for a long time and present it to a wider public. Finally I managed to do it. My host was its present owner Ivica who was thrilled to tell me everything about the house’s rich history. The adrenalin which takes over every visitor of this beauty when they enter is just indescribable. It is instant and it teleports you right into its rich past.

The house was built in 18th century by the members of Mimbelli family, famous shipowners who gained their wealth from wheat trade through Russia and China. In the brightest moments of their business they decided to present their wealth through such a palace in a small town like Orebić. The most expensive pieces of furniture were ordered, the family paid attention to every detail. Most of the original pieces of furniture are still preserved and smiling to the visitors. The Wiehler gobelins, Biedermeier furniture, antique Murano chandeliers, dressers made of rosewood from Kashmir, Belgian and English porcelain, copper dishes and an entire row of details made this house one of the most exclusive ones in Dalmatia of that time. Such luxury when choosing the most expensive materials of that time should not come as a surprise because Mimbelli’s were extremely rich, and at the peak of their power they had as many as 33 sailing boats, which they used to sell the Russian wheat all over the world. When decorating the house in Orebić, the family went so far as to order that the walls be manually painted. So in the end as much as 4 million egg yolks were used for this undertaking. What says the most of that quality is also the fact that the walls are still mostly preserved – excellent and authentic, almost 300 hundred years after they were painted. In time, the house was enriched with souvenirs coming from the Far East. Among other objects there was a Ming dynasty vase which was stolen during the partisans’ rampage and pillage during the Second World War.

There is an interesting story about the ending of the Mimbelli lineage in Orebić. Anton Mimbelli brought a governess from Russia, and his only son Baldo fell in love with her daughter. Since the parents thought she was lowly and of other religion, the marriage could not receive their blessing, and in spite of them Baldo swore he would never get married. And so it was, and in his will Baldo asked to be buried in Orebić, where he ordered a family mausoleum to be constructed by the great Croatian sculptor Ivan Rendić. In his testament he asked for the mausoleum’s dome to be painted in gold every two years, so that the passers-by would see that there lay the Mimbelli family, on the cemetery above Orebić. And the beautiful girl, symbolizing Baldo’s unfortunate love, was carved inside the mausoleum, and covered in golden leaves. This is an incredibly sumptuous tomb of the family which left an indelible trace in the history of Orebić, especially as donors and benefactors who provided finances to construct the city water system, renew the Franciscan church, etc…

Before his death Baldo sold the house to a famous maritime family Župa, whose last descendant, Matko, passed away in 2004. Matko was a famous collector, one of the founders of the Maritime museum in Orebić and its long-term director, as well as the director of the Korčula tourist board. As a memorable person on Pelješac he used to host different ambassadors in the Mimbelli house, as well as actors, writers and other highly positioned personalities from the former state. Everyone, absolutely everyone who travelled through Pelješac and Korčula wanted to spend at least one night there. There was even a well known saying that only the president Tito never dropped by. Had he known what kind of labels the vine basement hid, he would have probably not missed the opportunity.

 

A charismatic beauty as this one surely does not exist today in Dalmatia and had the circumstances been different, the state apparatus would have repurchased it a long time ago from its previous owners. The house is for sale today and through Forgotten Dalmatia you can get in touch with the owner. I am proud to have become friends with him and I have had the opportunity to enrich my collection of dalmatika with several interesting maritime documents from the Mimbelli and Župa family legacy, but also research this house and breathe in its beauty. I must use this opportunity to thank him for his friendship and the permission to photograph the house for our Instagram page, where thousands of people enjoyed the photos.

I can only hope that the new owners would preserve this beauty’s antique glow and renew it respecting its past and maritime tradition, which it undoubtedly deserves.

 

Igor Goleš

 

Guesthouse Mimbelli in Orebić, a house with a famous past, almost 300 years old.

Together with its garden has about 3000 m2, and the entrance is just 10 meters from the sea. The house is in great condition, each of the three floors has 200 m2 (with a large salon and four rooms), a separate vine cellar and a loft. The house also has large gardens and several other economic buildings, parking places and it’s fenced in by high walls, offering the owners exquisite privacy!

The house is sold together with its antique furniture and has a great market value.

Considering the exclusivity of the house and its past, this is one of the most exclusive and special objects for sale now in the Middle and South Dalmatia.

The price is 1.8 million Euros, and if the buyer contacts the owner through Forgotten Dalmatia, they will obtain a special discount of 2 per cent on the entire sum (agency’s fee excluded).

Igor Goleš

Tijekom svojih đirada po Dalmaciji i obilaženja najstarijih i najkarizmatičnijih kuća, došao sam i do čuvene kuće Mimbelli u Orebiću. Slušao sam o ovoj ljepotici u više navrata te dugo planirao snimiti je i pokazati široj publici. Naposljetku sam i uspio.  Ugostio me  njen današnji vlasnik Ivica i oduševljeno prepričao njenu bogatu povijest. Adrenalin koji  svakog posjetioca ove ljepotice prožme prilikom ulaska jednostavno je jednostavno, djeluje trenutno te vas teleportira u njenu bogatu prošlost.

Kuću su sagradili u 18. st. pripadnici obitelji Mimbelli, čuveni brodovlasnici koji su se obogatili trgovanjem žitom preko Rusije i Kine te su, u najsvjetlijim trenucima svog poslovanja, odlučili svoju moć i  bogatstvo prezentirati gradnjom jedne ovakve palače upravo u malom Orebiću. Naručivali su se najskuplji komadi namještaja, pazilo se na svaki detalj, a mnogi  od prvotnih komada namještaja se i danas neuništivo smješkaju posjetiteljima – Wiehlerovi gobleni, bidermajeri, antikni murano lusteri, komoda od drva ruže iz Kašmira,  belgijski i engleski porculan, bakreno posuđe te niz drugih detalja,  učinili su ovu kuću jednom od najekskluzivnijih u Dalmaciji tog vremena. Ovakva raskoš kod odabira najskupljih materijala tog vremena ne treba čuditi jer Mimbelliji su bili ekstremno bogati, a na vrhuncu svoje moći imali su čak 33 jedrenjaka kojima su trgovali ruskim žitom po cijelom svijetu. U svom ukrašavaju kuće u Orebiću obitelj je išla toliko daleko da su naručili i oslikavanje svih zidova pa je naposljetku utrošeno čak 4 milijuna žumanjaka u ovaj pothvat. O kvaliteti rada i danas nam svjedoče zidovi koji su, u najvećoj mjeri, izvrsno i autentično očuvani, gotovo 300 godina nakon oslikavanja. S vremenom, kuća se oplemenjivala suvenirima s dalekog istoka pa je, između ostalog, u njoj bila i vaza iz dinastije Ming koja je otuđena u partizanskom divljanju i pljačkaju tijekom II. svjetskog rata.

Uz kraj loze Mimbelli u Orebiću veže se zanimljiva priča. Anton Mimbelli doveo je iz Rusije  guvernantu u čiju se kćer njegov sin jedinac Baldo zaljubio. S obzirom na to da su roditelji smatrali da je ona nižeg roda i druge vjere nisu mogli blagosloviti taj brak, a Baldo se u inat njima zakleo da se nikada neće ženiti. Tako je i bilo. Baldo je oporučno zaželio da bude pokopan u Orebiću gdje je i naručio izradu obiteljskog mauzoleja  od velikog hrvatskog kipara Ivana Rendića. U testamentu je zaželio da se kupola mauzoleja svako dvije godine boji zlatnom bojom kako bi svi prolaznici vidjeli da na groblju povrh Orebića počiva obitelj Mimbelli, a sama isklesana ljepotica u mauzoleju koja simbolizira Baldovu nesretnu ljubav ukrašena je zlatnim listićima. Nevjerojatno raskošna grobnica obitelji koja je ostavila veliki trag u povijesti Orebića, osobito kao donatori i dobrotvori koji su financirali izgradnju gradskog vodovoda, obnovu franjevačke crkve itd.

Baldo je prije svoje smrti kuću proda slavnoj orebićkoj pomorskoj obitelji Župa čiji posljednji potomak Matko umire 2004. Matko je bio poznat kao veliki kolekcionar, jedan od osnivača Pomorskog muzeja u Orebiću i njegov dugogodišnji ravnatelj te direktor turističke zajednice općine Korčula. Kao znamenita osoba na Pelješcu često je u kući  Mimbelli ugošćivao razne veleposlanike, glumce i književnike, te druge visoko pozicionirane osobe iz bivše države. Svi, apsolutni svi,  koji su bili na proputovanju Pelješcem i Korčulom htjeli su tu provesti barem jednu noć. Poznata je izreka da jedino predsjednik Tito nije u tu kuću svratio, a da je znao kakve etikete je krio njen vinski podrum vjerojatno to ne bi ni on propustio.

Još jedna ovako karizmatična ljepotica zasigurno ne postoji danas u Dalmaciji i u nekim drugim okolnostima, država bi je odavno otkupila od sadašnjih vlasnika. Ona se danas prodaje i preko Zaboravljene Dalmacije  možete stupiti u kontakt s vlasnikom.  Ja sam ponosan što sam se u međuvremenu sprijateljio s njim i imao priliku za svoju zbirku dalmatike doći do nekoliko zanimljivih pomorskih dokumenta iz ostavština obitelji Mimbelli i Župa,  ali i istraživati je i udisati njenu ljepotu.  Ovim putem mu zahvaljujem na prijateljstvu i dozvoli da se kuća snima za našu Instagram stranicu, gdje su u njenim fotografijama mogle uživati tisuće ljudi.

Nadam se samo da će novi vlasnici ovoj ljepotici ostaviti stari sjaj i obnoviti je u duhu njene prošlosti i pomorske tradicije kako to ona, nesumnjivo, i zaslužuje.

Igor Goleš
